latestPosts.caption:
Kareena Kapoor Khan (@kareenakapoorkhan) is Indian cinema’s most enduring and joyous face, but her work and a good meal—more specifically her mother’s Sindhi curry and aloo tuk—are what it takes to make her happy. “Acting has always been a passion for me. Acting and food—that’s what brings me joy,” she shares. 

It should; Kareena has been acting for more than half her life. But now, at 44, she is re-evaluating her career trajectory. “Doing less is doing more,” says the actor who, until a few years ago, would average five or six films a year. To be clear, she still loves her job, but slowing down means signing fewer projects and roles with more depth. 

“It’s not about quantity anymore. It’s about choosing the right roles, ones that challenge me and excite me,” she says. “I want to preserve my energy, my talent, myself.” No chaos, no performative busy-ness, no need to prove anything to anyone. Mornings are her new luxury. “The first hour of my day? That’s mine,” she says with a possessiveness one usually reserves for a vintage Chanel bag. If her mornings are about solitude, her weekends are about connection. And food. Glorious, unapologetic food, which very often looks like wood-fired pizzas one day and Malabar-style stew the next, in what she calls “the happiest part of the house”— the kitchen. “We love cooking together as a family—Saif, the kids, me—we’re all in the kitchen,” she says. 

At the link in bio, @meghna.pant chats with the star about why her bandwidth is sacred now.

latestPosts.caption:
It’s been 25 years since we first saw Kareena Kapoor Khan (@kareenakapoorkhan) up close. She was just 20, but we all knew she was already a bona fide A-list movie star, because, even then, her presence was undeniable. In the years that followed, we got used to her wide doe eyes, her defined jawbones and her generous smile. She entered the pop culture hall of fame as the unstoppable Poo from ‘Kabhi Khushi Kabhie Gham’ (2001), spouting self-love idioms two decades before Gen Z adopted them. 

It wasn’t always easy. She was, after all, an actor who came of age during Bollywood’s peak era of harsh objectification. Quite often, her private life was the subject of entertainment-news headlines. Of course, there were the film-family comparisons that you’d expect, but tabloids seemed to even track her weight like some tally of national importance. 

These days, Kareena’s rarefied talents see her balance light-hearted roles with those loaded with gravitas. She played a street-smart sex worker (‘Chameli’), a single mom (‘Jaane Jaan’) and a hardened cop (‘Buckingham Murders’)—all unrecognisable portrayals in which the actor has continued to push herself and her audiences into brave new territory. “Everyone sees Poo and Geet as joyous characters because they are so vibrant, so alive. But for me, true joy comes from reinvention. From challenging yourself, digging inwards and finding something new,” says the 44-year-old actor. 

At the link in bio, @meghna.pant chats with the Bollywood icon who has cemented her legacy as a fourth-generation actor.

latestPosts.caption: When the face card is so lethal you don’t even need to see the face. Any guesses on our new cover star? 😏

Whichever way you look—on the news or otherwise—times are tough. Are you reeling under existential angst? Are you struggling with an inability to cope? Is nameless dread pulling you down? Is insomnia ruining your life? If you ask bibliotherapist Ella Berthoud (@infinite.ellaberthoud) for a remedy for any of these ailments, she’ll find the solution in a book.

We’re all familiar with the world of platitude-dense self-help books that tell us how to not give a f*ck, how to win friends and influence people and be highly effective people. Let go! Be a badass! Berthoud, however, turns to another avenue to find a cure—fiction.

Go to Berthoud with a situation that needs remedying, be it a tendency to sleep too much (or too little) or being stuck in the wrong career, and you’ll come back with a reading list that will somehow help you wrap your head around your conundrum—a novel cure, if you will. As anyone who likes to read will tell you, there are few things that feel better than being lost in a good book. Berthoud just matches one (or 10) to your current state of mind more accurately.

At the link in bio, @shallfall chats with @infinite.ellaberthoud about her truly novel career.

Artwork: Jishnu Bandyopadhyay (@jishyouwish)

~
For our first anniversary, The Nod’s all about bringing a little joy back into our stressed-out everyday lives. All through June, we’ll be sharing stories that’ll make you smile, surprise you (in a good way), and lift you up. Because honestly, life’s too short not to give dopamine a shot. 
~

I also quite often get women in their mid-thirties who are thinking about whether they want to have a child or not. For all these things we give a cure says Berthoud. using a novel,'.

latestPosts.caption:
A few weeks ago, the world of science was shaken by a new discovery—a colour no one else has seen before and only a select few can see even now. 

For those not hooked on the news cycle, the colour was discovered by researchers from the US who had laser pulses fired into their own eyes. While stimulating specific cells in the retina, they claimed to have witnessed a blue-green colour that scientists have called ‘olo’. And since it’s not every day that we wake up to a new colour, the fashion industry is contemplating its stance. After all, what does a colour only a few can see mean in our image-centric world? At the link in bio, @byrheamulani chats with people in the industry to find out.

childPosts.alt: Photo by The Nod on June 03, 2025. May be an image of magazine and text that says 'Could olo's inaccessibility catapult it into the exclusive zone of quiet luxury, where covert branding is the norm? "In an era where 'quiet luxury' is no longer about beige minimalism but about owning something rare, this is an an opportunity for new luxury brands to lead with innovation and create a signature shade that's not rooted in nostalgia but in discovery," says fashion designer Mayyur Girotra.'.

Photo by The Nod on June 03, 2025. May be a black-and-white image of text that says 'Girotra particularly sees potential for this in the bridal market, where trend cycles are often driven by colour. Remember when everyone was a pastel bride, or earlier this year when sage green was the hottes colour for a walk down the aisle? "Olo, with its otherworldly depth, could symbolise a bride stepping into uncharted territory," he says.'.

latestPosts.caption:
Ever stepped into a freezer to boost blood circulation? Or tried out the human equivalent of a vacuum-sealed bag to ease pain caused by varicose veins? Or spent an hour in a pressurised metal box sucking on oxygen to reduce inflammation? As flippant as these posers may sound, these are all healing mechanisms rooted in science on offer at the New York Art Deco-inspired, 446-key Fairmont Mumbai (@fairmontmumbai). In a rare departure for a chain hotel—it shares a wall with Mumbai airport’s Terminal 2 its owners, Shrem Airport Hotels, have invested in a “longevity program”. 

Housed in a part of the spa called the Blu Xone (derived from the term coined for regions populated by people leading exceptionally long and healthy lives) are facilities like cryotherapy, intermittent vacuum therapy (IVT), and hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT), which are otherwise found only in destination spas such as Dharana in Shillim, near Lonavala, and Pema Wellness near Visakhapatnam.

At the link in bio, @travellerprasad takes you on a tour of the hotel's spa that goes well beyond the average Ayurvedic and Swedish massages chain hotels usually have on offer.

latestPosts.caption:
Feeling anxious lately? You’re not alone. Every year, new data emerges to prove that the human race is not in the best place. In March, the World Happiness Report suggested that India (once again) slipped to its lowest ever spot in the World Happiness Report, ranking 118 out of 147 countries—below Bangladesh, China, Palestine and Ukraine. 
 
Between all the conventional markers of living well—a good job, a fat salary, a compatible partner—it seems the one palpable feeling we are chasing is a small dose of everyday happiness. But somehow, most of us are pretty lousy at it. So, for our first anniversary, we decided to give dopamine a shot. 
 
Over the course of this month, we will bring you stories that will help you cope with these anxious times. Some of them will make you smile (a poop ritual that doubles as a bonding exercise with your bffs? We got it), others may shock you a little (busyness, confirms cognitive scientist @lauriesantosofficial, professor at Yale, is making us unhappy), or help you delve deeper into cultivating and bringing back happiness into our day-to-day lives (don’t miss author @gretchenrubin’s happy-habits guide). 

If happiness was a person, our cover star—perhaps the most joyous face in showbiz—would be the literal embodiment of it (keep your eyes peeled for this today). And as an extra treat this week, there is a playlist, curated by The Nod’s in-house audiophiles, of songs that will most likely lift you up. Because you know what? Happiness is contagious. 
 
The Voorhes / Gallery Stock
latestPosts.alt: Photo by The Nod on June 01, 2025. May be an image of magazine, poster and text that says 'FIRST ANNIVERSARY RSARY n Bring back the JOY How to live your happiest, healthiest life in these anxious times'.

latestPosts.caption: Bandhini dots, zardozi embroidery, and Devanagari script. No, we’re not talking about a clothing collection. We’re talking about shoes from the new wave of homegrown sneaker brands that are currently popping up all over Instagram. The ones that promise sharp design, solid storytelling, and price tags that don’t make you flinch—brands that even the most die-hard sneakerheads could get behind. Maybe it’s time to lace into it. Link in bio.

Pooja Mor (@poojamor) and Cameron Lamb (cameronlamb) are from opposite ends of the world—he’s Australian, born in Sydney, she’s from Bareilly, India. Their work takes them to New York, London, Paris, and Los Angeles. She’s usually modelling for international magazines like Vogue or Le Figaro and fronting brands like Polène and Saks. He’s a producer of award-winning films and a publisher who jets between film sets around the world. Yet their first date was at an Indian restaurant in London, and eventually, less than two years after meeting each other, the couple decided that home would be with each other. For now, that’s Paris, where the two were married in November 2024 in an intimate town-hall ceremony. They followed it up with a celebration at Pooja’s family home in Rohtak in April 2025. 

At the link in bio, The Nod's @butoolbegum chats with the couple about putting together a truly personal celebration that would mark the start of their future together.

Photographs: Nick Hudson (@hudsonphoto), Onkar Naik (@infinityprojkt)

It really felt like both our families came together in that moment, as Pooja and did.'.

latestPosts.caption: As you bounce between blazing heat and sudden downpours wondering if the weather’s having an identity crisis, we’re here to make at least one thing less confusing: your streaming picks. Whether you’re in the mood for a slow-burn mystery like ‘Thudarum’, where Mohanlal searches for a missing car, or you’re still not over ‘Sex and the City’ and curious to see what Carrie’s scribbling about in the latest season of ‘And Just Like That’..., there’s something to match every mood swing. Throw in Timothée Chalamet channelling Bob Dylan in ‘A Complete Unknown’, and you’ve got yourself a watchlist worth ignoring your weather app for. Link in bio.

latestPosts.caption:
'Sister Midnight', a pulpy, nocturnal tale of marriage, survival, and urban alienation, follows the story of an arranged marriage between Uma (Radhika Apte) and Gopal (Ashok Pathak) as they navigate marital life, domesticity, and adulthood from the confines of their single-room chawl in Mumbai. A modern feminist fable, and a classically comic tale of disastrous misfits, director Karan Kandhari’s (@deathpunkbaby) prowess as a storyteller shines in his capacity to mime a pitch-black, deadpan, quasi-Wes Anderson sense of humour in the most mundane of situations. 

But for all its grit, 'Sister Midnight' isn’t a poverty postcard. Kandhari dodges the noble-poverty aesthetic many filmmakers fall into when tackling India’s margins. “People are neurotic, no matter their class,” he says. “I wanted to capture that without exoticising it.”

At the link in bio, @anwesh_writes chats with the 44-year-old filmmaker  about his loud, funny, electric film that's impossible to ignore.

#sistermidnight

My artistic heroes-Bok heroes Dylan, Sylvia Plath, William Blake, Robert Altman Altman-were were anarchic in both art and life," he says.'.
